posts.name: 4907 mentor & enthusiast
posts.cooked:
We are encountering a reprojection error of between 1.4 and 1.6 when calibrating our system using the provided documentation. I'm curious if anyone can provide further insights into what this indicates. According to the documentation, the "Check the Latest Calibration Result" card should display a low reprojection error, ideally below 1.0. Our current error rate of 1.5 is above this threshold, which may impact our application's functionality, particularly in scenarios requiring precise object recognition for improved Megatag performance.

To address this, we have meticulously adhered to the calibration guidelines, utilizing a printed 8.5x11 inch Aruco tag sourced from the Limelight website. However, several potential factors could still be contributing to the elevated error. First, the quality of the tag print might not meet the required standards; ensuring the tags are clear and free of distortion is crucial. Additionally, environmental factors such as lighting conditions must be optimal to prevent glare or shadowing affecting tag detection.

Moreover, verifying the accuracy of the camera setup is essential. This includes checking if the camera is properly focused and free from obstructions. The positioning of the tags must adhere strictly to recommended specifications to ensure accurate marker detection. Lastly, reviewing the code for any potential anomalies or outdated algorithms that might hinder performance could uncover overlooked issues. Exploring recent software updates or seeking community discussions might offer established solutions to mitigate this issue effectively. By systematically addressing each of these areas, we aim to reduce the reprojection error and enhance overall system performance.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: A printed board wouldn't work. I needed a higher precision Charuco board to achieve the level of accuracy required for precise reprojecting at a 0.5 px range. These boards have uniquely coded fields, allowing calibration even when partially obscured or positioned less than ideally, and they're more robust against image noise. This makes them ideal for accurate measurements. You can find these Charuco targets on platforms like [Calib.io](https://calib.io/products/charuco-targets), priced at €116.

Looking for a reliable and affordable way to calibrate your cameras for 2025? I’m excited to share a new product: Charuco Calibration Targets, designed specifically for teams looking to achieve professional-quality camera calibration without breaking the bank. These targets are made from 6mm aluminum composite, ensuring they remain flat and provide consistent, accurate calibration results. Not only are they durable, but they are also cost-effective, offering comparable quality to professional-grade targets at a much lower price. Highly recommended—they may seem affordable, but they deliver amazing results.

posts.name: Bjorn Janssen
posts.cooked: I don’t know if this will solve it, but I know that we experienced something similar when we flipped the width/height of the tiles on the board. So you might want to consider trying that in the calibration settings.

posts.name: 4907 mentor & enthusiast
posts.cooked: Thank you for your feedback! It seems like your result (~1.6) is still better than using the default calibration, but I'm curious if it holds up for next year.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: You’d need to provide the estimation data after performing pre-post calibration and verify it empirically. From my past experience with Limelights, the factory calibration was superior to what I could achieve on my own, though that was before I acquired the boards I currently use.

If you have a tablet to display the calibration board, you can achieve sub-millimeter accuracy relatively easily since the screen is extremely flat. Just make sure to measure the size of the elements on the screen with calipers because they may not match those on a printed board.
